title: Wednesday, 1st February, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Hi there

PM11:01am

Our daily chat about stuff

PM11:01am

Have a pic for today

11:01 am
PM11:01am

PM11:01am

Evolution of the Murphy

PM11:01am

From potato to corrupt public official

11:02 am
PM11:02am

It's from Josh Brown's brilliant post, which I think was linked to the other day over on the right

PM11:02am

http://thereformed...d-italian-friends/

PM11:02am

Apparently that post has got 1m views so far

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Extraordinary

PM11:03am

I've met a few times. He's very good company

PM11:03am

And a mate of Cardiff

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Anyway, have a scroll through that -- some fascinating cartoons

PM11:03am

None that i saw about Scots tho Bryce

BE11:04am

I like Josh. Cracking writer, clear of thought.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

And am prepared to accept his ignoring of the Jocks as a mercy rather than a slight.

PM11:04am

Yeah

undefined
11:04 am
PM11:04am

SO

PM11:04am

Do we talk about TalkTalk?

PM11:05am

Suppose we could note the wider market first

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Footsie up 53 points so far

PM11:05am

Again very mixed

PM11:05am

Mixed is the new pants on/pants off

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Mixed-ish. It's mostly up. 52 points on the FTSE is pretty decent by recent standards.

PM11:06am

Yeah, that's true

PM11:06am

Brexit debate underway in Westminster -- but we want to avoid that

11:06 am
PM11:06am

George Parker captures it rather nicely here https://www.ft.com...-893c-082c54a7f539

undefined
PM11:07am

But let's talk about TalkTalk

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Numbers bad, guidance held, Dido off.

Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 168.07, up 11.57 (+7.39%), High: 172.70, Low: 161.70, Volume: 3.17m
BE11:08am

You can attach whichever of those three reasons you want to that share price reaction.

11:08 am
PM11:08am

Q3s here http://www.investe...1702010700086637V/

BE11:08am

The idea here is that Dunstone's back in charge, having taking "non" off his business card.

PM11:09am

ha

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Board moves here http://www.investe...1702010700116640V/

BE11:09am

Which might or might not fit with all the stuff in the statement about a renewed focus on customer growth and etc.

BE11:10am

Three months ago it was meant to be a renewed focus on reducing churn. So, clearly, something's changed.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

(Including their prices, as we noted yesterday.)

BE11:10am

One would've thought "growth" would mean "uh, the divi's going to be sacrificed here". But no one seems to be reading it that way.

BE11:11am

Let me get RBC to summarise where we are. They're reckoning it's a turnaround play now.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

We believe TalkTalk is at a pivotal point in its history. Having got the business through the hacking issue and refreshed packages, the outgoing CEO is able to hand over to the new CEO Tristia Harrison (formerly MD of consumer) with the business showing positive net adds in 4Q and FY17 guidance unchanged. More importantly, founder Charles Dunstone returns full time, having announced he will be stepping down from Carphone Dixon's in May.

BE11:12am

We see this move as a positive. With fixed-line prices at the top end of the market being pushed higher by BT and Virgin, the opportunity for a low-cost operator is arguably expanding. With this is mind, the fact that 45% of new customers are taking fibre and 40% are taking TV suggests the quality of gross adds is being helped by spin down from more expensive platforms. With high re-contracting rates, churn is likely to be constructive.

BE11:12am

Here it comes. "Yield" and "bid". Both rather uncertain attractions to my mind, but what do I know ......

11:12 am
BE11:13am

The appeal for investors is twofold, in our view.
1) Dividend: TALK is paying a near 10% dividend this year. We think that could be continued at the same rate next year given slightly improved net debt exiting FY17 and probable cash coverage next year. The cash cost of the dividend is c.£150m and is mostly covered this year by EBITDA (consensus of £310m) less capex (£160m) and working capital (£30m). Next year, if EBITDA is slightly better (current consensus £328m) and capex and working capital in line, we see no reason to cut the dividend. Investors can therefore expect this year's final and next year's dividend, totalling some c. 25p per share. A net entry point of only 125p/share.

PM11:13am

10%?!?!?!

BE11:13am

Don't buy something at a 10% yield expecting to get a 10% yield. History tells us that's a good rule of thumb.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Seem to remember having this exact conversation around Anglo American this time last year.

BE11:15am

Which turned out well for investors, I guess, irrespective of the divi. But sadly for TalkTalk, it doesn't have enough copper wire to be geared into a commodities rally.

BE11:15am

Back to RBC.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

2) End Game. Talk Talk has long been seen by many in the market as a sub-donor giving up share, squeezed by others in the market. If the repositioning can take hold, and Charles Dunstone can demonstrate growth in the value segment, we believe the natural end game could again be seen as a sale to one of the standalone mobile operators keen to bolt on TALK as a key to convergence.

BE11:15am

Sigh.

BE11:16am

As we've said about a zillion times, Vodafone, Sky etc have run the numbers on Talktalk endlessly. They keep the spreadsheets open permanently.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Because the maths is simple: "is the price +30%-40% low enough that it's worth buying the customer base?"

PM11:17am

I'm still gawping at that dividend -- and RBC saying it will be held this year and next

PM11:17am

"mostly covered"

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Yeah, I know. Anyway, the bid theory puts a floor on the stock, I guess. But it's a counterintuitive reason to buy it, because simple observational evidence suggests it'd have to go lower before it could go higher.

BE11:18am

Have Jefferies.

BE11:19am

Today's announcement that Charles Dunstone will assume the role of Exec Chairman from May raises hope that TALK will now focus regaining 'value' credentials and restoring retail growth. This maximises the company's long-term prospects. But renewed retail effort casts doubt on viability of future EBITDA growth. Mr Dunstone says that divi policy post-Mar17 is under review. We see flat DPS as untenable given 3.0x leverage constraint imposed by recent bond issue.

11:19 am
PM11:19am

What do we know about this Tristia Harrison?

PM11:19am

Background wise

BE11:19am

Nothing.

11:19 am
PM11:19am

Former marketer apparently

PM11:20am

Actually I have a snap from Ameet Patel at Northern Trust

BE11:20am

Good-o.

11:20 am
PM11:20am

He's not a fan (of the company)

PM11:20am

Actually, not a fan of the board rejig

PM11:20am

Finally the underwhelming current TalkTalk CEO Dido Harding has announced she is leaving. Could have been a potential positive catalyst - opportunity to hand over reins to someone that knows how to run a telco business and can salvage some value. Instead they have chosen an internal promotion - Tristia Harrison - whose path has been via Carphone Warehouse i.e. floor space retail background (same as Dido) as opposed to any proper experience of running a telco network provider. Telco is not retail. You wouldn't send in Terry Leahy to run BT, so why the other way around? A wasted opportunity. Anyone still holding out hope for TalkTalk should give up. Even if there's some short term relief/hope.

11:20 am
PM11:21am

But -- price up 7.4%

PM11:21am

Shares wise

PM11:21am

extraordinary

11:21 am
undefined
PM11:21am

Pearson top of the Footsie risers

PM11:22am

Haven't seen any upgrades

11:21 am
PM11:22am

Otherwise we would have jumped on em of course

PM11:22am

They'e sold this Brazilian thing -- but can't see an RNS on it

PM11:23am

Pueri

11:23 am
PM11:23am

They bought this four years ago - now selling it back to the vendor

PM11:23am

So much for the big push into Latam

PM11:23am

Suppose if it was a mistake, good to back out of that

11:23 am
PM11:24am

You know at Pearson -- in the corporate finance department -- they used to refer to the company as "The Ark"

PM11:24am

Had two of everything

Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 635.50, up 16.5 (+2.67%), High: 638.00, Low: 620.50, Volume: 1.75m
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Hm. One has to remember that a 2% move in Pearson isn't what it used to be, given the whole thing's only valued at £5bn these days.

undefined
PM11:25am

Ms Harrison at TalkTalk

11:25 am
PM11:25am

...

BE11:25am

Yes?

PM11:25am

The name seems to have rung a bell here in the newsroom

11:25 am
PM11:25am

Is/was there an Andrew Harrison at Carphone?

BE11:25am

The CEO? Yes. Yes there is.

PM11:26am

Not related by any chance, are they?

11:26 am
BE11:26am

I believe they're married.

PM11:26am

Oh

BE11:26am

Tristia used to use her maiden name, I think. Clarke.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

T|hey met at Carphone. Dunstone was a matchmaker.

BE11:27am

Charles does seem to keep the people he knows in the tent.

undefined
11:27 am
BE11:28am

Otherwise ....... among the risers .........

BE11:28am

Should mention the drug stocks.

Hikma Pharmaceuticals PLC (HIK:LSE): Last: 1,864, up 40 (+2.19%), High: 1,886, Low: 1,842, Volume: 275.13k
11:28 am
Shire PLC (SHP:LSE): Last: 4,478, up 98.5 (+2.25%), High: 4,498, Low: 4,443, Volume: 630.27k
AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,271, up 77 (+1.84%), High: 4,295, Low: 4,243, Volume: 898.04k
BE11:28am

Trump bump.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Drug industry meeting yesterday wasn't the worst case scenario ....

BE11:29am

.... as in, a bunch of CEOs getting a lecture about why they're evil.

BE11:29am

Instead, we got ......

11:29 am
BE11:29am

https://www.ft.com...-893c-082c54a7f539

BE11:30am

Donald Trump has said his administration will significantly cut the length of time it takes to win regulatory approval for new medicines, prompting a rally in pharmaceuticals stocks.

BE11:30am

...... So ....................

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Excuse my brief wander into the history here, but it's quite important.

BE11:30am

What you're looking at here is the 1962 Kefauver-Harris Amendment, signed into law by JFK.

PM11:00am

Welcome to Markets Live, here at FT Alphaville

11:31 am
BE11:31am

It's an amendment to the pre-war Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act, which regulated medicines much as it regulated chewing gum and mascara.

BE11:31am

(Genuinely. There are chapters of the bill specifically about chewing gum and mascara.)

BE11:32am

Pre the amendment, the rough rule applied was: "Does this kill you? No? Okay, fine then."

11:32 am
BE11:32am

After that came the FDA's three-stage New Drug Application process, much as it's used today.

PM11:32am

Fascinating Bryce

BE11:32am

And applied it retroactively. Every drug already on the market had to be classified as "works!" or "snake oil".

11:32 am
BE11:33am

It can be argued -- by me, for one -- that the The Kefauver-Harris Amendment did more for the the health and safety of the global population than any other piece of legislation before or since.

BE11:33am

Trump, tho.

BE11:33am

Trump knows better.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

He's built some casinos, and only run out of money four times

BE11:33am

..... so he's clearly qualified to figure out where to cut the slack from an NDA process that's grown over the past 70 or so years out of the life work of a million doctors and scientists.

BE11:33am

“We’re going to be streamlining the process, so that from your standpoint when you have a drug, you can actually get it approved if it works instead of waiting for many, many years,” the US president said during a meeting with industry executives at the White House on Tuesday

11:33 am
BE11:34am

I mean ............ Jees.

PM11:34am

hehehehe

BE11:34am

So, yeah, it wasn't solely a "cut the price of drugs!" meeting. That's good, I guess. For investors.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

The lack of aggressive tone might represent the general thrust of WH policy, I guess.

BE11:34am

Or it might just reflect The Donald's deep fragility ... his innate desire to be liked by the audience he's facing at any given moment.

PM11:35am

Actually, that's very true

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Perhaps we got lots of talk about regulatory streamlining and easier onshoring of trapped cash, etc, because it was audience friendly.

BE11:35am

It played well in the room.

PM11:35am

He screams at sectors from afarr -- and then has great meetings with them

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Precisely.

BE11:36am

And next week, when the room might be filled with folk from the National Coalition on Health Care, will the message switch back to kicking ass on price gouging and bringing back the factories to US shores?

BE11:36am

Of course it will.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Does any of this form into a reason to buy Shire or Hikma this morning?

BE11:36am

Of course it doesn't.

BE11:37am

Anyway, here's some analysts to try and force sense onto all this noise.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Credit Suisse incoming.

BE11:37am

In general, given how investors have been specifically concerned on the potential for changes in how drugs are priced in the US, we believe the broader the discussion and debate becomes and the more it includes issues that have been headwinds for the industry, the better the outcome may be for the sector. Obviously this is an issue where the details will matter, so we await those details as we move forward to understand what the true impact of the new administration’s policies will be on the companies that we cover.

BE11:37am

Drug pricing remains top of mind. President Trump has made a number of comments both during his campaign and since becoming the President highlighting the cost of prescription medicines in the US and his desire to bring those costs down. Based on the discussions coming out of the meeting, it appears that some of the complexities around how drugs are priced in the US were discussed, so the focus was not strictly on the relatively high list prices that tend to dominate media coverage of the issue.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Comments were also made around attempting to adjust trade agreements that could potentially lead to increased drug prices outside of the US, helping to at least partially offset any further pricing pressure seen in the US. We like that our companies are beginning to take a more proactive approach to the issue of drug pricing. As we have previously published, we also continue to believe that the key for all of our companies remains developing unique, innovative products in areas with significant unmet medical need to maintain maximum pricing power. A shift towards a more value-based pricing system would likely also reward companies that deliver true innovation.

BE11:37am

Corporate tax reform an area of potentially significant benefit.
Effective tax planning by our larger cap US-based multinational companies has helped lower their effective tax rates but has also led to significant amount of cash and earnings being trapped overseas. We are sensing an increasing likelihood for a repatriation holiday and/or possible broader tax reform, which could give our US-domiciled companies greater flexibility in how they use their extensive cash balances to invest in the business, execute on business development or return cash to shareholders. While we have seen some smaller scale M&A in recent months, we believe there are many other attractive SMID cap targets still available, with the pace and size of deals potentially increasing should we see more comprehensive corporate tax reform.

BE11:37am

Impact of potential reforms to be seen over time. In addition to drug pricing and corporate taxes, the impact of changes to the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) as well as regulations concerning the FDA could have wide-ranging impacts on the sector. We await more details on these topics before estimating the potential impact, but we are encouraged by the broader scope that the discussions in Washington seem to now be taking.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

And Morgan Stanley ............ Slightly more sector-ish, but still pinned to the Trumpet.

BE11:38am

Bull points on why the bounce is durable. 1) President Trump's initial meeting with drug industry leaders appeared collaborative, and drug pricing was just one of a wide range topics discussed. See our Jan. 31 report "Mkt breathes sigh of relief after President's mtg, but next actions unpredictable." 2) Pharma is trading near historical low valuations and the sector is under-owned, 3) The drug industry is self-policing on pricing, and its public relations efforts will improve its image.

BE11:38am

Bear points on why the bounce is likely a "dead cat bounce" 1) The President Trump meeting was not a "worst case" event, but he repeated his interest in the US government paying lower prices. And he could still issue criticisms and single out select companies as he has done in other industries. 2) President Trump's focus on the difference between US prices and other developed countries is not necessarily good for the industry, since it may be difficult for President Trump to drive other countries to pay higher prices. 3) It remains unclear if annual industry list price increases in the high single digits are sustainable, and the insurance system does not appear inclined to accept lower rebates.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Legislative risks to drug prices could include Medicare direct negotiations and dual eligibles reverting back to Medicaid. On the former, the risk seems relatively low because Congressional Republicans have historically been opposed. However, the risk from the latter could be a realistic threat because Republicans may be willing to horse-trade it to help fund future healthcare proposals. The CBO has scored Medicare dual eligible rebates positively—$116B savings over 10 years by the Obama administration (less than 4% of our US Biopharma spending estimate of greater than $3 trillion over the next 10 years).

BE11:39am

PE multiple relative to market is at its lowest since 2012. The price-to-forward earnings multiple for Pharma, Biotech, & Life Sciences vs. the market is ~0.9 currently. Since 1976, this marks the third period of time that the sector multiple has traded below the market. On an absolute basis, the forward multiple is ~15.4x, which is far off the lows of ~10x historically. We think this disconnect between the relative and absolute could be due to drug pricing concerns that is causing a more negative perception of the sector relative to the overall market.

BE11:39am

Hedge Fund net exposure to Pharma is also at the lowest since 2012. According to Morgan Stanley Prime Brokerage, Hedge Fund exposure to Pharma is at lowest levels since 2012 after it peaked in July '15; Hedge Funds started to actively reduce their exposure to Pharma since September '15 after the Hillary tweet on "price gouging."

11:39 am
BE11:39am

[/rant]

undefined
PM11:39am

Good rant tho Bryce

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Well .... I'm a drugs bore. I've apologised for that before on here.

BE11:41am

Anyway, what else is happening? Zoopla placing seems to have gone okay.

Zoopla Property Group PLC (ZPLA:LSE): Last: 377.10, up 10.9 (+2.98%), High: 383.40, Low: 376.00, Volume: 22.02m
11:41 am
PM11:41am

This after them buying this Hometrack business

PM11:41am

Data / analytics

PM11:42am

Data data data

11:42 am
PM11:42am

The new McKinsey

PM11:42am

Tells you stuff you already know

PM11:42am

But it's different in the property world, i accept that

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Response is "bolt on deal, seems to make sense, price not outrageous".

BE11:43am

Also a fairly small placing (5% of share capital)

BE11:44am

Notable that Daily Mail isn't buying into it, which I guess suggests that stake is in the disposal group.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

But we probably could've guessed that already.

Daily Mail and General Trust (DMGT:LSE): Last: 703.50, up 10.5 (+1.52%), High: 704.50, Low: 692.00, Volume: 371.49k
BE11:45am

Here's Numis.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Complimentary to Zoopla’s existing business and moves Zoopla forward on a core part of strategy to develop its data services business. Hometrack provides partners with market leading valuation tools and data intelligence. Hometrack has a strong position in the Australian market which Zoopla feel offers significant growth opportunities (not a market they have been present in previously). The deal is expected to be earnings and margin enhancing on an adjusted basis in first full year of ownership.

BE11:45am

Consideration of £120m, with £108m due on completion and
£6m on each of the first and second anniversaries. At £120m business valued at 14.7x EBITDA for year to 31 December 2016 (13-16 revenue CAGR +15%). Financed via existing cash resources, a new £75m term loan and an equity placing of up to 5% of Zoopla equity. Management note they are currently in discussions relating to further small acquisitions.

BE11:46am

On trading the Board is pleased with current trading across both
divisions, with Agent partners continuing to grow since year end and Comparison Services continuing to see solid switching volumes across each vertical.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

All in looks a sensible deal at fair price, and reassuring trading comments. At face value we would expect low single digit percent EPS accretion in 2018 as a result of the deal (1 – 2%), no change to underlying estimates on back of trading update.

BE11:46am

And Liberum, post the 9am management call.

BE11:46am

The call highlighted the multiple synergistic opportunities this deal presents, the most apparent opportunity is cross selling Hometrack or a Hometrack/PSG combined product into the c.23,000 property partners that ZPG has, especially considering Hometrack currently sell into zero estate agents. On a stand-alone basis, Hometrack has market leading products with 100% customer retention rates and considerable headroom to grow into exc. the synergistic opportunities when combining both product suites.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

Hometrack currently generates c.90% of its revenues from mortgage lenders and that should come as no surprise given Hometrack provides its products to 15 out of the top 20 mortgage lenders in the UK as well as all four of the leading Australian mortgage lenders. Management stated that currently only 10% of new mortgages are being underwritten by automated valuation models (AVM), currently new mortgages are predominantly being underwritten by surveyors but this market should continue to tend towards the new cheaper technological option. Hometrack currently has a 100% retention rate highlighting the importance and market leading nature of its products, consequently one would expect Hometrack should be the main beneficiary of this market shifting to technology.

Hometrack is currently used by zero estate agents, this is a significant opportunity for ZPG as they have relationships with c.23,000 property partners and Hometrack can leverage ZPG's relationship to cross sell its current product portfolio as well as the new innovations of a combination of ZPG products. Another opportunity is monetising this on the consumer end of the internet portal sites, whilst zoopla.co.uk and primelocation.co.uk currently provide free automatic valuations to consumers, in the future ZPG could offer in-depth reports into the current valuation of users properties for a one-off fee, which will be a new high margin revenue source. Zoopla portals have an estimated 11.5m monthly unique users and the majority are non-transactional, this potential innovation gives ZPG an additional mechanism to monetise this vast amount of traffic.

BE11:47am

This acquisition has given ZPG a foothold in the Australian market and management stated that the Australian unit is an important part of the business and they they are committed to growing the business further. This gives ZPG a greater insight into the workings of the Australian market but it could be seen as a pre-cursor into ZPG's future ambitions. The barriers to entry that supports Hometrack's market leading position is the algorithm and the data, the algorithm could be exported to other geographies and management stated they were currently in a partnership with an Italian firm but that it was early stages. Whilst it is near impossible to transpose the internet portals business into new geographies, the Data services and the back-end property services businesses could be successfully expanded into other geographies.

PM11:47am

It actually sounds an interesting bolt-on

11:47 am
PM11:47am

And the placing -- this was at 365p yeah?

PM11:48am

Tight discount

BE11:48am

Indeed. Note also that Zoopla was, I think, at or near a record high when the trigger was pulled.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

It's quite a turnaround from when we were talking about Zoopla as being second to Rightmove and therefore nowhere in the market.

BE11:49am

Which was about to be eaten by that OnTheMarket estate agent collective thing.

PM11:49am

Forgotten all about OnTheMarket

11:49 am
BE11:49am

I think most people have.

BE11:50am

It does seem Zoopla's strategy of broadening and diversifying rather than defending its core business (as in, buying USwitch etc) has been a success. And it's not often we say that.

undefined
11:50 am
BE11:51am

Rolls upgrade from UBS worth noting.

Rolls-Royce Holdings PLC (RR.:LSE): Last: 677.00, up 9.5 (+1.42%), High: 689.00, Low: 671.00, Volume: 2.96m
BE11:51am

New analyst, in part, resulting in a sector rejig.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Rolls-Royce is an unloved stock, with a high level of scepticism about management's ability to deliver adequate levels of FCF in 2018-20. We estimate that cash generation is close to £850m in 2019E and £1.1bn in 2020E, including £640-680m from the non-Civil Aerospace activities. We believe investors ascribe little value to cash improvement in 2019/2020. Over 2017, we think investors will gain more comfort on management's "grip" on the business. 2016 was the first year without warnings since February 2014, and the 2016 outlook was raised slightly in Jan 2017. The FY16 results are due on 14 Feb, with potentially further cost-reduction announced (UBSe £100m one-off charge).

BE11:52am

Our industrials and commodities teams are getting more constructive on the short-cycle industrial end markets, and we retain our positive stance on the defence spending outlook in the US and the UK. RR’s non-Aerospace businesses have c50% of sales in defence, 30% in marine, and 19% in energy and industrial end markets. Our review of the end-market capex and growth profile leads us to upgrade our estimates by 10%, on average, in 2017-18. Our 2018 EBIT estimates are 12%/7% ahead of cons. in Power Systems/Defence. Positive news on these businesses should translate into good cash flow generation (c80%, on average), supporting the overall group cash improvement.

BE11:52am

Our bespoke model of RR Civil cash flows suggests that the cash gradually progresses from a c£160m loss in 2016 to £635m in 2020. Our assumptions on OE deliveries and aftermarket revenues are conservative and reflect our global A&D stance on widebody oversupply. Today, RR is below peers in terms of sales per employee and inventory turns, and should benefit from cost cutting, higher volumes and favourable FX.

11:52 am
BE11:53am

Cash has always been the largest unknown at RR and a source of polarised views. That is why we think it is the best metric to value the stock. On the back of our analysis, FCF starts to turn positive in 2018E in the Civil Aerospace division, triggering a higher level of cash generation at the group level. Some major outstanding uncertainties, such as the SFO investigation, have just been resolved, which is a relief. For our price target, we consider that 5% is an attractive level of FCF yield for the A&D sector (avg. is 5-6%).

BE11:54am

One day, someone will work out the definitive way of working out how much cash Rolls actually generates. The shares will lock at a price into perpetuity and we'll never have to talk about it ever again.

undefined
11:53 am
PM11:54am

Breaking news

PM11:54am

Sir Ken Morrison, who was instrumental in growing supermarket Morrisons into one of the UK's largest retailers, has died aged 85 following a short illness, his family said.

PM11:54am

Was life president of the grocer he built from scratch

11:54 am
PM11:55am

That's a snap from PA btw

BE11:55am

Quite a man, and quite a life. Condolences to his family.

PM11:56am

11:56 am
undefined
PM11:56am

Nothing from Trump yet

PM11:56am

He's obv having a lie in

11:57 am
PM11:57am

Should note in passing, one tweeter worth following is https://twitter.com/RoguePOTUSStaff

PM11:57am

It's nicely done

BE11:58am

There's a quite convincing theory that that account's bogus, though I'm not entering into the debate.

11:58 am
PM11:59am

BE12:01pm

Q317 results to December have disappointed (clean NPAT €13.5m vs our forecast for €16m)
and the market will focus on the headline change in FY17 guidance from €245-255m to
€225-235m.
Q3 RASK was down 15.7% yoy vs our forecast of a 12.5% decline, although costs were
better with CASK down 7.3% yoy vs our 5.3% forecast and ex-fuel CASK down 40bp yoy vs
our 20bp.
However the focus will be on the Q4 adjustment, with the mid-point €230m PAT guidance
implying a €15m loss vs the €0.8m profit seen last year. The company has broken down the
€20m guidance hit as €5m weather disruption, €5m negative fuel price moves and a €10m
hit from current promotional yields. This last point will again be the focus with concern RYA’s
Bucharest and Sofia base openings are impacting more than expected. Given this we will
likely reduce our FY17 PAT forecast from €243m to €227m and next year from €249m to
€230m.
With that said, we believe that the business model remains intact, with pricing parity
between Wizz and RYA normalising by April, with the two airlines sharing the bulk of growth
in the CEE region between them and with Wizz driving unit costs down with the increasing
impact of the A321 in the fleet mix.

BE12:01pm

As such, while the stock may show some weakness ahead of Ryanair’s Q3 results
next Monday, we remain convinced that Wizz remains undervalued to its peers
given that a) its 100% leveraged to the fast growing CEE region b) that it has the
highest leverage to new technology with its significant A321 order book c) that it
has the best leverage to ancillaries of any European airline and d) that free cash
flow remains substantial with net cash still hitting €1bn by end FY19.
